ygData.msgSnippet: Jeff, your paper is a great explorations of the properties of the CPPN encoding in 3D.  I do have a couple thoughts on the target-based experiment: First, the

Subject: Re: New paper on evolving 3D objects with CPPNs (and 3D-printing them)
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=54567749; y=xvWj2ql3aPAcirFnvjfYYH9_lxqpgAnpbslETfv3yRxAig6J5owR

Jeff, your paper is a great explorations of the properties of the CPPN
enco=
ding in 3D.  I do have a couple thoughts on the target-based
experiment:

F=
irst, the evolved results from the target-based runs all look really
intere=
sting.  They do look like they were carved with a lathe, which is
kind of s=
urprising.  Maybe you should seek funding from a
banister-design company!

=
In any case, regarding the connection to my paper with Brian, we
observed b=
asically two phenomena:  One is that if the target is
sufficiently complex,=
 it simply cannot be reached.  However, when the
targets were simple enough=
, in fact they could be reproduced reliably. 
Yet the problem when the targ=
ets actually were reproduced well was that
their CPPNs were two or three ti=
mes as large as the CPPN that generated
the original target.  So our messag=
e was not simply that you can't reach
targets, but that even when you do, y=
ou pay a price with inelegant
representation complexity.  Your case appears=
 somewhere in the middle:
the attempts do not look bad, although they are n=
ot perfect
reproductions either.

I am guessing that the target you chose i=
s thus sort of on the
borderline of complexity that is almost reproducible,=
 like the "Eye"
target in our paper.  What would be interesting would be to=
 see the CPPN
structures of the best approximations to see whether they are=
 encoding
the fundamental concept or stringing it together inefficiently.  =
I know
you said that the morphologies themselves don't look "piecemeal," bu=
t
they could still be constructed in a piecewise fashion mathematically. 
F=
or example, figure 8i has some subtle ridges suggestive of unnecessary
unde=
rlying complexity.

Another interesting factor is the number of evaluations=
 to get within
90%.  It varies across your treatments, but 30,000 evaluatio=
ns or so
looks like a reasonable expectation with your system.   With a
pop=
ulation of 15 in Picbreeder, that would be 2,000 generations, which
is a re=
ally large number for the complexity of the target object (you
can also see=
 objects of similar complexity in EndlessForms from 10 or 20
generations). =
 So I think your experiment is pretty consistent with ours
overall, though =
it wasn't geared at making the same point.

ken

--- In neat@...=
m, Jeff Clune <jeffclune@...> wrote:
>
> Hello everyone-
>
> Hod Lipson and=
 I have a new publication on evolving 3D morphologies
with
> CPPNs, which e=
xplains the algorithm behind EndlessForms.com.
>
> PDF:  http://goo.gl/HRXL=
D
>
> Most of you will at least enjoy quickly scanning the figures to see
t=
he
> evolved shapes, which are higher resolution and different than those
o=
n
> EndlessForms.com.  You can also see a picture of the evolved shapes 3D
=
> printed.
>
> The diversity of shapes I was able to discover just playing =
with the
system
> myself for a few hours is pretty incredible, which is a t=
estament to
Ken's
> CPPN encoding. Additionally, I ran tests with and witho=
ut recurrence
in the
> CPPN genome, and with different inputs to the CPPN, =
and you can see
the
> difference those choices make in the resultant object=
s. For example,
with
> CPPN recurrence, the shapes often look more fractal.=
 I believe (but
please
> correct me if I am wrong) that this is the first p=
ublication with a
test of
> CPPNs with and without recurrence.
>
> FInally,=
 I conducted target-based evolution by evolving CPPNs to match
a
> goal obj=
ect. I'd be interested to hear if you think the goal was
reached,
> and how=
 to interpret these results in light of Brian Woolley & Ken
Stanley's
> pap=
er on CPPNs not being able to reach target 2D objectives.
>
> What I like b=
est about being able to evolve 3D objects is learning how
the
> CPPN search=
 space works: mutations frequently produce very sensible
> variation. For e=
xample, the two 3D printed elephants in figure one are
> brothers, and are =
close relatives of the three elephant-looking things
in
> figure 4 (b2-4). =
It's nice to see mutations have such smooth, sensible
> effects, instead of=
 creating wildly different objects.
>
> As always, please let me know your =
thoughts and questions.
>
> Best regards,
> Jeff Clune
>
> Postdoctoral Fel=
low
> Hod Lipson's Creative Machines Laboratory
> Cornell University
